text: Scalar, Vector Perturbations and Effective Hawking Radiation of
label: H1

text: Cylindrical Black Holes in f ( R ) and Ricci-Inverse Gravity
label: H1

text: b, 1 Ahmad Al-Badawi , c and Abdelmalek Bouzenada
label: body

text: a Department of Physics, University of Science & Technology Meghalaya, Ri-Bhoi, Meghalaya, 793101, India
label: body

text: c AS245 Department of Physics, Eastern Mediterranean University, 99628, Famagusta Northern Cyprus, via Mersin
label: body

text: b Department of Physics, Al-Hussein Bin Talal University, 71111, Ma’an, Jordan
label: body

text: d Laboratory of Theoretical and Applied Physics, Echahid Cheikh Larbi Tebessi University 12001, Algeria
label: body

text: This paper investigates scalar perturbations and quasinormal modes (QNMs) associated with
label: body

text: cylindrical black holes constructed within the frameworks of f ( R )-gravity and Ricci-Inverse ( RI ) gravity.
label: body

text: Moreover, we study the modified Hawking radiation in these black hole solutions and analyze the effects
label: body

text: of coupling constants. These modified theories, which extend general relativity by introducing higher-order
label: body

text: curvature corrections and additional geometric terms, provide a rich platform for exploring deviations from
label: body

text: standard gravitational physics. The study begins by revisiting the cylindrical black holes in these modified
label: body

text: gravity theories, where the effective cosmological constants respectively, are represented by Λ f ( R )
label: body

text: related to the coupling constants unique to each framework. Afterwards, the QNMs, intrinsic damped os-
label: body

text: cillations of the black hole space-time, are analyzed to probe the stability of the system, with the effective
label: body

text: potential V revealing the impact of the modified gravity parameters. Additionally, the thermodynamic prop-
label: body

text: erties of the black holes are examined through the lens of the Generalized Uncertainty Principle (GUP),
label: body

text: which introduces quantum corrections to Hawking radiation. The GUP-modified Hawking temperature and
label: body

text: entropy are derived, demonstrating significant deviations from classical results and highlighting the quantum
label: body

text: gravitational effects in these modified frameworks. By linking QNMs, thermodynamics, and quantum cor-
label: body

text: rections, this work not only deepens the understanding of modified gravity theories but also offers potential
label: body

text: observational pathways to test their validity.
label: body

text: Keywords: Black holes; modified gravity theories; cosmological constant; Geodesics motions
label: body

text: BH solutions within f ( R ) and RI -gravity theories
label: H2

text: Scalar Perturbations and the Effective Potential: QNMs
label: H2

text: Effect of GUP on Quantum Tunneling of Scalar Particles in f ( R ) and RI -gravity theories 12
label: H2

text: For decades, black holes have captivated scientists as some of the most fascinating and enigmatic entities in the
label: body

text: universe, primarily due to their unique role in Einstein’s theory of gravity. While many black holes are believed
label: body

text: to form from the gravitational collapse of massive stars (see Refs. [ 1 – 5 ]), others, such as primordial black
label: body

text: holes, may emerge from density fluctuations during cosmic inflation or from early-universe topological defects.
label: body

text: Observational breakthroughs, including measurements of black hole spins in X-ray binaries, gravitational wave
label: body

text: detections from binary mergers via LIGO, the imaging of the supermassive black hole in galaxy M87 by the
label: body

text: Event Horizon Telescope [ 6 – 9 ], and the discovery of star-black hole binary systems through radial velocity
label: body

text: measurements [ 10 ], strongly corroborate the existence of black holes. These advances not only deepen our
label: body

text: understanding of gravity but also provide invaluable insights into the properties and dynamics of black holes.
label: body

text: Stephen Hawking’s groundbreaking contributions have significantly advanced our knowledge of black hole
label: body

text: physics. At the core of a black hole lies a singularity [ 11 ], a region of infinite density where classical physical
label: body

text: Surrounding this singularity is the event horizon [ 13 ], a boundary beyond which
label: body

text: not even light can escape the black hole’s immense gravitational pull [ 14 ]. Black holes are fundamentally
label: body

text: characterized by three parameters: (i) mass [ 15 ], (ii) electric charge [ 16 ], and (iii) angular momentum [ 17 ].
label: body

text: Hawking’s pioneering work explored quantum phenomena at the event horizon, leading to the concept of
label: body

text: Hawking radiation [ 18 ]. This discovery revealed that black holes are not entirely “black” but instead emit
label: body

text: radiation due to quantum effects, gradually losing mass over time. Such findings connect thermodynamics
label: body

text: with quantum mechanics by introducing the notions of black hole temperature ( T H ) and entropy ( S ) [ 19 , 20 ].
label: body

text: Additionally, Hawking’s research linked black holes to gravitational waves [ 21 ] and quantum states [ 22 ], laying
label: body

text: the foundation for efforts to unify quantum mechanics and general relativity (GR) [ 23 – 26 ]. These theories
label: body

text: continue to inspire contemporary investigations into the quantum nature of spacetime [ 27 , 28 ].
label: body

text: Among the modified theories of gravity, f ( R )-gravity has garnered significant attention [ 29 – 31 ]. This
label: body

text: framework generalizes the Ricci scalar R in the Einstein-Hilbert action to an arbitrary function f ( R ) [ 32 , 33 ],
label: body

text: introducing corrections that can explain phenomena such as the accelerated expansion of the universe. While
label: body

text: f ( R )-gravity holds promise, it faces theoretical and observational challenges [ 34 – 36 ]. Furthermore, the in-
label: body

text: terplay between black hole physics and spacetime modifications is evident in scenarios involving Lorentz
label: body

text: violations, where the geometry near the event horizon influences the Hawking radiation spectrum and tem-
label: body

text: perature. Such deviations from GR predictions provide potential avenues for constraining Lorentz-violating
label: body

text: QNMs have long been recognized as essential tools for probing the stability of spacetime configurations,
label: body

text: such as black holes or branes. QNMs, which manifest as damped oscillations with discrete spectra, are intrinsic
label: body

text: to the black hole’s structure, independent of the initial perturbations [ 42 ]. The study of QNMs, initiated in
label: body

text: [ 43 – 45 ], has illuminated their significance in characterizing black hole mass, angular momentum [ 46 , 47 ], and
label: body

text: stability [ 46 ]. Moreover, in the context of AdS/CFT correspondence, QNMs elucidate the thermalization rates
label: body

text: in the boundary theory [ 48 ]. Beyond stability analysis, QNMs contribute to our understanding of Hawking
label: body

text: radiation [ 49 ] and offer insights into quantizing gravity. The boundary conditions governing QNMs-ingoing
label: body

text: waves at the event horizon and theory-specific conditions at infinity-underscore their role in black hole physics
label: body

text: Recently, RI - gravity has emerged as a compelling alternative framework within the realm of modified
label: body

text: gravity theories, offering new insights into some of the most perplexing phenomena in theoretical physics,
label: body

text: including causality violations, wormholes, and stellar structures [ 51 – 77 ]. This class of theories generalizes
label: body

text: the standard Einstein-Hilbert action by incorporating higher-order curvature terms and other geometric
label: body

text: quantities, leading to modifications of the field equations that accommodate rich and diverse cosmological
label: body

text: and astrophysical implications. Among these, the study of cylindrical black holes [ 77 ] plays a crucial role,
label: body

text: as they provide simplified yet insightful models to explore the effects of these modifications in a highly
label: body

text: symmetric spacetime. Unlike the more commonly studied spherical black holes, cylindrical configurations
label: body

text: inherently possess an anisotropic structure, which enables a detailed investigation of directional dependencies
label: body

text: and dynamical behaviors unique to modified gravity theories. QNMs associated with cylindrical black holes
label: body

text: further enhance their utility as probes of stability, as these damped oscillations are highly sensitive to the
label: body

text: underlying spacetime geometry and the parameters of the RI -gravity model. Moreover, cylindrical black
label: body

text: holes offer an ideal framework for studying thermodynamic properties, such as Hawking radiation and entropy,
label: body

text: particularly when quantum corrections like those introduced by the GUP are considered. These investigations
label: body

text: not only shed light on the deviations from GR but also highlight the intricate interplay between modified
label: body

text: gravity, black hole thermodynamics, and quantum phenomena. By examining these systems, RI -gravity
label: body

text: provides a robust platform for addressing unresolved questions about the nature of spacetime, the dynamics
label: body

text: of exotic matter, and the potential observational signatures that could bridge the gap between theoretical
label: body

text: predictions and empirical evidence. Consequently, the study of cylindrical black holes in this context serves
label: body

text: as a stepping stone toward a deeper understanding of gravitational physics beyond Einstein’s framework.
label: body

text: The paper is organized as follows: In Sec. 2 , we present the cylindrical black hole solution within f ( R )
label: body

text: and RI -gravity frameworks. Sec. 3 focuses on the QNMs, analyzing the effective potential and their stability.
label: body

text: In Sec. 5 , we explore the impact of the GUP on the Hawking radiation and thermodynamic properties of
label: body

text: the black holes. Finally, Sec. 6 concludes the paper, summarizing the results and discussing potential future
label: body

text: BH solutions within f ( R ) and RI -gravity theories
label: H1

text: In this section, we consider a cylindrical black hole solution formulated within GR, in the context of modified
label: body

text: gravity theory. Therefore, we begin this section by introducing this BH solution in cylindrical coordinates
label: body

text: ( t, r, φ, z ) given by [ 78 ]
label: body

text: f ( r ) + r 2 dφ 2 + α 2 r 2 dz 2 ,
label: body

text: where the metric tensor g µν and its contravairant form are given by ( x 0 = t, x 1 = r, x 2 = φ, x 3 = z )
label: body

text: Here M denotes mass of BH, α > 0 is a positive constant, and the coordinates are in the ranges −∞ < t < ∞ ,
label: body

text: r ≥ 0, φ ∈ [0 , 2 π ), and −∞ < z < ∞ called the temporal, radial, angular and the axial coordinates,
label: body

text: This space-time ( 2.1 ) satisfied the Einstein vacuum field equations with a negative cosmological constant
label: body

text: Below, we review this black hole (BH) solution in the context of modified gravity theories. Specifically,
label: body

text: we focus on two prominent theories: f ( R )-gravity and RI -gravity. These modified theories extend GR by
label: body

text: altering the gravitational Lagrangian, introducing additional degrees of freedom, and potentially offering
label: body

text: insights into the nature of dark energy, dark matter, and the early universe.
label: body

text: Our main motivation is to investigate the scalar perturbations around the modified black hole solutions
label: body

text: obtained in the gravity theories mentioned earlier. Scalar fields play a crucial role in modified gravity theories
label: body

text: and can lead to deviations from the standard GR predictions. Finally, we study the Hawking temperature,
label: body

text: which is a key feature of black hole thermodynamics. The Hawking temperature, associated with the emission
label: body

text: of black hole radiation, is influenced by the spacetime geometry and the gravitational modifications consider
label: body

text: in the current study. By calculating the Hawking temperature for the black holes in f ( R )-gravity and RI -
label: body

text: gravity, we can compare the results with those from GR and gain insights into how these modifications affect
label: body

text: the thermodynamic properties of black holes.
label: body

text: In the framework of f ( R )-gravity, the action is modified by an arbitrary function of the Ricci scalar R ,
label: body

text: which leads to modified field equations. This introduces a richer structure to the gravitational dynamics, as
label: body

text: the function f ( R ) allows for deviations from the standard Einstein-Hilbert action.
label: body

text: The Einstein-Hilbert action in f ( R )-gravity theory is given by
label: body

text: d x 4 √ − g ( f ( R ) − 2 Λ m ) + S M ,
label: body

label: body

label: body

text: scalar A = g µν A µν ̸ = R − 1 , and the anti-curvature tensor A µν = R − 1
label: body

label: body

text: d x 4 √ − g ( f ( R , A , A µν A µν ) − 2 Λ m ) + S m .
label: body

label: body

text: model of RI -gravity are given by

text: ρ + P µν + M µν + U µν + Λ m g µν = T µν ,

text: + 2 g ρν ∇ ρ ∇ α ( f A 2 A σκ A σµ A ακ ) − g ρν ∇ α ∇ ρ ( f A 2 A σκ A σµ A ακ ) .

text: Scalar Perturbations and the Effective Potential: QNMs
label: H1

text: From the expressions in Eqs. ( 3.10 ) and ( 3.11 ), it is evident that the effective potential governing the
label: body

text: scalar perturbations is significantly influenced by the coupling constants present in the modified gravitational
label: body

text: theories. In the context of f ( R )-gravity, the effective potential is modulated by the constants α 2 , α 3 , and
label: body

text: α 4 , which arise from the functional form of the gravitational action and the associated field equations. These
label: body

text: constants determine the strength and nature of the interaction between the scalar field and the modified
label: body

text: curvature terms, thereby affecting the propagation of scalar fields.
label: body

text: Similarly, in the framework of RI -gravity, the effective potential is influenced by a different set of
label: body

text: parameters: α 2 , β 1 , β 2 , and γ . These constants arise from the specific modification used in RI -gravity.
label: body

text: The interplay between these parameters governs how the scalar field interacts with the modified gravitational
label: body

text: background, which affects the dynamics of scalar perturbations in this model.
label: body

text: We have generated Figure 1 , which illustrates the effective potential for scalar perturbations within the
label: body

text: framework of f ( R ) gravity, considering various values of the coupling constants. The figure shows how the
label: body

text: effective potential evolves with changes in the values of the coupling constants α 2 , α 3 , and α 4 . As these
label: body

text: constants increase, the potential gradually rises, indicating that the strength of the scalar perturbations is
label: body

text: affected by the modifications to the gravitational action.
label: body

text: Furthermore, we compare this potential to the standard GR case by setting α 2 = 0, α 3 = 0, and α 4 = 0,
label: body

text: effectively reducing f ( R ) gravity to the GR limit. This comparison highlights the differences between the
label: body

label: body

text: Effect of GUP on Quantum Tunneling of Scalar Particles in f ( R ) and RI -gravity
label: H1

text: Hawking radiation [ 81 – 95 ] is a quantum mechanical phenomenon that arises near the event horizon of black
label: body

text: holes. Modifications to the standard Hawking radiation, inspired by the Generalized Uncertainty Principle
label: body

text: (GUP) [ 96 – 99 ], provide a window into the interplay between quantum mechanics and gravity. The GUP-
label: body

text: modified Klein-Gordon equation (GUPKGE) is a central tool for exploring these corrections [ 100 ]. In this
label: body

text: section, we calculate the GUP-modified Hawking radiation of cylindrical black holes described by two metrics
label: body

text: in f ( R )-gravity ( 2.13 ) and RI -gravity ( 2.23 ). To this end, we employ the quantum tunneling approach and
label: body

text: solve the GUP-modified wave equation for scalar fields propagating in these backgrounds. However, since
label: body

text: both metrics of those modified gravity theories are structurally identical to each other, we consider Eq. ( 2.22 )
label: body

text: as a generic line-element of cylindrical black hole of cosmological constant Λ. Then, we shall replace Λ with
label: body

text: The GUPKGE for a scalar field Ψ is given by [ 100 ]
label: body

text: where α GUP is the GUP parameter and m p is the mass of the scalar particle. The above equation includes
label: body

text: quantum gravitational corrections due to the GUP and will be used to derive the corrected Hawking temper-
label: body

text: To solve the GUPKGE ( 5.1 ), we assume the following wave function for the scalar field:
label: body

text: Ψ( t, r, φ, z ) = exp
label: body

text: ℏ S ( t, r, φ, z )
label: body

text: where S ( t, r, φ, z ) is the action, expressed as:
label: body

text: S ( t, r, φ, z ) = − E t + W ( r ) + j φ + k z + K.
label: body

text: Here, E is the energy, j represents the angular momentum, k denotes the separation constant associated
label: body

text: with the z -direction, and K is a complex constant. Substituting Ψ into the KGE and retaining only the
label: body

text: leading-order terms in ℏ , we obtain:
label: body

text: ( ∂ t S ) 2 = g rr ( ∂ r S ) 2 + j 2
label: body

text: After substituting the ansatz ( 5.3 ) in Eq. ( 5.4 ) and focusing only on radial motion ( j = 0, k = 0) and
label: body

text: substituting the equation can be simplified to
label: body

text: E 2 = g rr ( W ′ ( r )) 2 + m 2
label: body

text: Reorganizing and solving for W ′ ( r ), we get:
label: body

text: which naturally yields the following integral solution for W ( r ):
label: body

text: Close to the horizon r h , where g tt ( r h ) = 0, the metric function ∆( r ) = g tt ( r ) can be expanded as:
label: body

text: where ∆ ′ ( r h ) is the derivative of ∆( r ) with respect to r at the event horizon and κ denotes the surface gravity:
label: body

text: Moreover, the radius of the event horizon is expressed as follows:
label: body

text: Using Eq. ( 5.8 ) and the metric functions, the integral for W ( r ) near the horizon simplifies to:
label: body

text: E 2 − ∆ ′ ( r h )( r − r h ) m 2 p (1 − 2 m 2 p α GUP )

label: body

text: This study provided a comprehensive analysis of the scalar perturbations and the GUP-modified thermo-
label: body

text: dynamic properties of cylindrical black holes constructed within the context of modified gravity theories,
label: body

text: specifically f ( R )-gravity and RI -gravity theories. We began by re-deriving the cylindrical black hole solu-
label: body

text: tions within these modified gravity theories. The effective cosmological constants were shown to depend on
label: body

text: coupling constants α i , β i , and γ , which characterize the respective theories, as reported in [ 77 ]. The results
label: body

text: revealed that these coupling constants significantly influenced the black hole dynamics compared to General
label: body

text: Using the Klein-Gordon equation ( 3.1 ), we analyzed a massless scalar field in the background of the
label: body

text: black hole constructed within the framework of f ( R )-gravity and RI -gravity theories. In this context, we
label: body

text: derived the effective potential V , as expressed in Eq. ( 3.9 ). We showed that this effective potential for scalar
label: body

text: perturbations was influenced by the constants α 2 coupled with R 2 , α 3 coupled with R 3 , and α 4 coupled with
label: body

text: R 4 in f ( R )-gravity theory. Similarly, in RI -gravity theory, the scalar perturbation potential was influenced
label: body

text: by the constants α 2 coupled with R 2 , β 1 coupled with A , β 2 coupled with A 2 , and γ coupled with A µν A µν .
label: body

text: Figures 1 – 2 illustrated the behavior of the effective potential V ( r ) in both f ( R )-gravity and RI -gravity
label: body

text: theories, and compared it with the results in the GR limit.
label: body

text: Moreover, Hawking radiation was analyzed within the framework of the Generalized Uncertainty Principle
label: body

text: (GUP). The GUP-corrected Hawking temperatures for cylindrical black holes constructed in the context of
label: body

text: f ( R )-gravity and RI -gravity theories were derived, as presented in Eqs. ( 5.25 ) and ( 5.26 ), which highlighted
label: body

text: the quantum corrections to black hole evaporation. The analysis demonstrated that the GUP parameter α GUP
label: body

text: causes a reduction in the Hawking temperature, leading to a slower rate of black hole evaporation compared
label: body

text: to the standard result in General Relativity (GR). This slower evaporation is a direct consequence of the
label: body

text: modified dispersion relations that arise from the GUP, which in turn affect the thermodynamic properties of
label: body

text: Additionally, the coupling constants of the modified gravity theories were shown to have significant effects
label: body

text: on the GUP-corrected Hawking temperature. Specifically, the coupling constants α 2 , α 3 , and α 4 in f ( R )-
label: body

text: gravity theory were found to influence the GUP-corrected temperature, modifying the black hole evaporation
label: body

text: rate compared to that in GR. Similarly, in the context of RI -gravity theory, the coupling constants α 2 , β 1 ,
label: body

text: β 2 , and γ were shown to significantly affect the GUP-corrected temperature. These modifications resulted
label: body

text: in notable deviations from the GUP-corrected temperature in the GR limit, thus emphasizing the impact of
label: body

text: the modified gravity framework on the thermodynamic properties of the black holes.
label: body

text: Furthermore, the GUP-corrected entropy was also calculated, as expressed in Eq. ( 5.37 ), which indicated a
label: body

text: significant deviation from the classical Bekenstein-Hawking entropy. This deviation arises due to the quantum
label: body

text: modifications introduced by the GUP, which alter the black hole’s entropy at the microscopic level. We also
label: body

text: derived the entropy expressions ( 5.38 ) and ( 5.39 ), respectively for cylindrical black holes in both f ( R )-gravity
label: body

text: and RI -gravity theories, highlighting the role of the coupling constants in these modified theories. In both
label: body

text: cases, we observed that the coupling constants influenced the GUP-corrected entropy, leading to substantial
label: body

text: changes compared to the classical entropy expression in General Relativity. These results underscored the
label: body

text: importance of considering both the GUP and modified gravity theories when analyzing the thermodynamic
label: body

text: properties of black holes, as the coupling constants played a crucial role in modifying the entropy and
label: body

text: temperature, thus providing deeper insights into the quantum nature of black hole thermodynamics.
label: body

text: Future directions for this study involve several promising extensions that could deepen our understanding
label: body

text: of black hole thermodynamics within modified gravity frameworks. One key direction is to extend the analysis
label: body

text: to rotating black holes (Kerr-like solutions) and higher-dimensional black holes within these modified gravity
label: body

text: theories. The inclusion of rotation and additional spatial dimensions could provide richer dynamics, such as
label: body

text: the effects of angular momentum on the GUP-modified thermodynamic properties, Hawking radiation, and
label: body

text: the scalar perturbations, potentially unveiling new phenomena not present in the static, four-dimensional
label: body

text: Another crucial avenue for future research is the exploration of the observational implications of the
label: body

text: modified Hawking radiation spectrum. Since Hawking radiation is theorized to be extremely weak and difficult
label: body

text: to detect, modifications introduced by the GUP and modified gravity could have significant effects on the
label: body

text: emission characteristics, such as its temperature, spectrum, or time evolution. Investigating the potential
label: body

text: for detecting these modified radiation signatures through black hole shadow imaging-such as that achieved
label: body

text: by the Event Horizon Telescope-or through gravitational wave signals from black hole mergers could offer
label: body

text: valuable experimental evidence supporting or challenging the theoretical predictions of GUP-modified black
label: body

text: hole thermodynamics. These observations could also help differentiate between different modified gravity
label: body

text: theories and provide deeper insights into the quantum nature of black holes.
label: body

text: Finally, an exciting direction would be to incorporate other quantum gravity approaches, such as loop
label: body

text: quantum gravity (LQG), into this framework. LQG, which provides a non-perturbative quantization of space-
label: body

text: time, might introduce further modifications to black hole thermodynamics at both the classical and quantum
label: body

text: levels. Exploring how these quantum gravity effects interplay with modified gravity theories could reveal new
label: body

text: aspects of black hole structure, such as the nature of singularities, the role of spacetime discreteness, and the
label: body

text: potential for a finite entropy or temperature at the event horizon. Integrating LQG with the GUP framework
label: body

text: may uncover additional corrections to the Hawking radiation, entropy, and perturbation spectra, and could
label: body

text: offer a unified view of the quantum structure of black holes across various quantum gravity paradigms.
label: body

text: These future directions promise to expand the scope of our current understanding and may pave the way
label: body

text: for groundbreaking theoretical and observational advances in the study of black holes, quantum gravity, and
label: body
